author: Brene Brown
statement: I am imperfect, and I am wired for struggle, yet I am absolutely worthy of love and belonging.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I recognize that my vulnerability is my truth and my courage. It might not always be comfortable, but it's never a weakness.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that my vulnerability is the true birthplace of my love, belonging, joy, courage, empathy, and creativity.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am willing to stay vulnerable because it's the path to true connection.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I choose to feel all my emotions, knowing that numbing the painful ones also numbs my joy.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I know my dark moments don't destroy my light; they define it. I release my fear of the dark to fully embrace my joy.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I now see that owning my story and loving myself through that process is the bravest thing I will ever do.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I allow myself to feel, understanding that numbing my pain also numbs my happiness.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that if someone isn't willing or able to love me, it doesn't diminish my inherent lovability.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I embrace who I am, knowing that true belonging comes from being my authentic self, not from changing for others.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I know that my belonging starts with my self-acceptance. As I believe I am enough, I gain the courage to be authentic, vulnerable, and imperfect.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I commit to talking to myself with the same kindness and compassion I would offer someone I love.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I don't need to chase extraordinary moments for happiness; I find it right in front of me by practicing attention and gratitude.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I see my imperfections not as inadequacies, but as reminders that I am connected to everyone else in this human experience.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I cultivate love by allowing my most vulnerable self to be seen and known, honoring the spiritual connection that grows from that offering with trust and respect.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am enough. My worthiness is a birthright, not something I have to earn.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I choose courage over comfort today, understanding that I cannot have both at the same time.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I dare to set boundaries, knowing it's an act of self-love, even if it risks disappointing others.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I recognize that shame is the fear of not being good enough, and I choose to challenge that fear.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that there is no innovation or creativity without the willingness to experience failure.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I acknowledge when I am 'crazy-busy' and recognize it as an armor, a way to numb my true feelings and needs.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am worthy of love and belonging, no matter my struggles or imperfections.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am willing to show up and be seen, even when I cannot control the outcome, because that is true courage.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that true belonging is not about fitting in; it's about being accepted for who I authentically am.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I practice gratitude and joy in moments of terror, reminding myself that to feel this vulnerable means I am alive.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I know that living with a whole heart requires me to take off the armor, put down the weapons, show up, and let myself be seen.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I embrace curiosity and compassion, understanding that judging others often stems from my own perceived deficiencies.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I choose integrity over comfort, choosing what is right over what is fun, fast, or easy.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I recognize that compassion is not a virtue but a commitment to showing up with empathy.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I acknowledge that regret can be the birthplace of empathy, especially when it comes from failures of courage.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that boundaries are not about pushing people away, but about creating space for compassion and preventing resentment.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I believe that the only unique contribution I will ever make in this world will be born of my creativity.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am learning that recognizing and leaning into the discomfort of vulnerability teaches me how to live with joy, gratitude, and grace.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I refuse to let the fear of what others think prevent me from living authentically and believing in myself.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that true power is unlimited and created with others, not taken from them.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I practice shame resilience by naming my shame, talking about it, owning my story, and sharing it with trusted people.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I accept that to feel shame is to be human, and I will not let it isolate me.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I know that empathy is a hostile environment for shame, and I seek connection and understanding.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I recognize that courage is a heart word, and its original definition means to tell the story of who I am with my whole heart.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am enough, and I will not negotiate my value with the world.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that when I numb difficult emotions, I also numb my capacity for joy and connection.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I choose to brave the wilderness, knowing that standing alone in my truth is a path to deep self-connection.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am committed to showing up and being seen, because it makes me a little braver each time.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I believe that the path to a deeper and more meaningful life is found through vulnerability.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I strive for healthy achievement and growth, not perfectionism, knowing perfectionism is a shield.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that true belonging requires me to be vulnerable, get uncomfortable, and learn to be present without sacrificing who I am.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I choose to be kind to myself, knowing that self-compassion is vital when I face struggles and imperfections.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I acknowledge that I am wired for connection, and when those needs are not met, I feel it deeply.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I believe that worthiness is a birthright, and embracing this belief opens up endless possibilities.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I choose to rumble with vulnerability, knowing that courage and fear are not mutually exclusive; I can be both brave and afraid at the same time.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I understand that loneliness thrives when I am afraid to reach out, and I commit to fostering connection.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I recognize that what I regret most are my failures of courage, and I use these regrets as a birthplace for empathy.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I know that my wild heart needs protection against constant self-evaluation and external judgment.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am learning that showing up and being seen is tough, but it's not as dangerous as getting to the end of my life and wondering 'What if I would have shown up?'

author: Brene Brown
statement: I allow myself to feel disappointment and pain without letting it define my worth or prevent me from trying again.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am committed to living a wholehearted life, embracing my imperfections and sharing my true self with the world.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I believe that my integrity is built on choosing courage over comfort and practicing my values, not just professing them.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I know that my ability to experience belonging is directly tied to my level of self-acceptance.

author: Brene Brown
statement: I am cultivating the courage to be imperfect, to set boundaries, and to allow myself to be vulnerable.
